content:
The St ela partita species studied by Conklin (see attached
sheets? has been displaced along the eastern seaboard by Styela
clava (a Korean was import) which we will use in a demonstration
5f Erescent formation and segregation. we will follow the first
few cleavages, up to about the 32-cell stage during the afternoon.
3. Histospecific enzyme markers of muscle and endoderm:
and alkaline phosphatase
The use of simple histochemical markers of certain histotypic
enzymes, including an characteristic of
muscle cell differentiation and alkaline phosphatase indicative of
endodermal development, served to open up ascidian embryos to a
realm of molecular analysis that was previously closed. We will
demonstrate current versions of these two reactions using 12-hour
(early tailbud) stages of Ciona. These embryos are provided at
the front of the room. Set up the two stainings as described in
the attached methods sheets. Both stains can be used sequentially
on the same specimens if you fix with the formalin fixative (15
min) and do the alkaline phosphatase stain first. You should try
the double stain: the result is striking!
Session II: 7:30pm-12:OOmn
4. Cholinesterase expression in cleavage-arrested embryos
One of the most exciting findings of classical experimental
embryology techniques with ascidians is the extreme autonomy of
development which the earliest blastomeres have. This autonomy
follows the Conklin fate map exactly and invariably and is why
such development was originally called "mosaic," because it
appreared to be a patchwork (mosaic) of predetermined parts. Eric
Davidson has referred to modern studies of ascidian development as
"neo-preformationism." The usual "classic" study was based on
blastomere isolations which are difficult, to say the least. A
potent parallel demonstration is a similar finding in embryos
which have been cleavage-arrested with the inhibitor of
microfilament assembly, cytochalasin B.
Some cytochalasin treated 8-cell stages are provided at the front
of the room. These were treated with 2 micrograms/ml cytochalasin
for 14 hr after the 8-cell stage. These are permanently arrested
8-cell stages which have differentiated MANY specialized proteins
and structures in the appropriate lineage blastomeres- it may
just look like an 8-cell stage to you; you are merely too sinful
see what is there. Try the cholinesterase stain on a sample of
these embryos. You might also try the alkaline phosphatase stain,
both work equally well to show variously that muscle lineages and
endodermal lineage cells continue to differentiate in the absence
of cell division and display thereby "mosaic" development.
